Introduction

This policy provides the framework for managers to address attendance issues and to promote attendance at work in a way that is consistent and reasonable and reflects that each member of staff's situation will be different.
Scope
The purpose of this policy and related guidance documents is to:
Enable managers to provide appropriate support to staff absent from work because they are unwell;
Provide a framework within which managers can take action to address issues of ill-health or sickness absence.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities

Managers are responsible for dealing with all incidents of absence in a sensitive, fair and  consistent  manner.  Managers  are also  responsible  for  the operation  of  the sickness  absence  process  which  includes  understanding  this  policy  and  related guidance  and  ensuring  that  they  are  appropriately  trained  to  manage  sickness absence and seek guidance from the Employee Relations Team where appropriate.

All Members of staff are responsible for informing their manager or the most senior person in charge of any sickness or absence, usually by telephone. Members of staff are also responsible for following this policy at all times.
Employee Relations  team are responsible for providing advice and guidance to managers and staff on managing sickness absence and providing specialist support in terms of absence management;

Occupational Health is responsible for providing a confidential advisory service to members of staff and managers on matters that relate to health in the workplace including adjustments required to secure an early return to work following illness or if permanent adjustments are required, ensuring they comply with the Equality Act 2010.

Trade Unions play a vital role in supporting members of staff during periods of absence and in relation to their return to work. They also work with managers to ensure the policy adhered to in a fair and consistent way.
Reporting Absence

On the first day of absence all members of staff must speak to their line manager, or nominated deputy, as soon as possible, to allow the line manager (nominated deputy) time to arrange cover. Medical staff are to telephone their department via the Divisional Rota Co-ordinator / Consultant in Charge as soon as it is clear they are unable to work indicating the reason for absence and the likely duration of absence if possible.

This must be before the shift starts and ideally no later than one hour before the shift is due to commence. Every effort must be made to contact the line manager (nominated deputy) in the first instance. Texting, e-mailing or leaving a message via a colleague is not acceptable as the default position. Additionally, members of staff on a training course, study leave or attending college must contact the line manager (nominated deputy).
Members of staff should explain;
The nature of the illness and in particular if it is likely to impact on service delivery or patient care e.g. infectious disease;
How long it is anticipated that the member of staff will be absent from work for.

If members of staff are absent from work and do not contact their line manager by the required time the line manager will attempt to contact them. If the member of staff has a concern about being contacted this can be discussed with an appropriate manager.
Certification
Members of staff must produce appropriate certificates as soon as possible for all sickness absences:
Sickness absence up to and including 7 calendar days must be covered by a Self-Certificate which can be obtained from the line manager;
Sickness absence which exceeds 7 calendar days must be covered by a ‘Statement of Fitness for Work' from a Doctor;
Initial and subsequent Statement of Fitness for Work, must be sent to the line manager within 3 working days of the date that the statement was issued.

If an member of staff fails to provide a Statement of Fitness for Work the absence may  be  considered  as unauthorised,  consideration  may  be  given  to  withholding occupational and/or statutory sick pay and in appropriate circumstances could be treated as a disciplinary matter.
Staying in Contact

It is important staff stay in regular contact with their line manager (nominated deputy) whilst they are absent from work. The frequency of contact should be agreed between the member of staff and the line manager (nominated deputy). Staff must contact their line manager if:
There are any changes to a diagnosis;
The anticipated length of absence changes;
The Statement of Fitness for Work is due to expire;
Another Statement of Fitness for Work is issued;
They know the date they will be returning to work.
Consideration may be given to withholding occupational and/or statutory sick pay if a member of staff fails to maintain the agreed level of contact with their line manager (nominated deputy).
Occupational Health

The Occupational Health department is available to give both general and specific advice on the fitness of a member of staff for work and likely return dates. Occupational Health Team will lead the Trust's staff Health and wellbeing and healthy lifestyle agenda and provide management advice and support to the Trust regarding health matters.
Line managers are expected to exercise discretion in referring to the Occupational Health department. The following guiding principles should be applied:

A referral should be completed for Occupational Health review when a member of staff has been absent from work for 28 calendar days unless the cause, duration and likely outcome of absence is already established where a later referral may be more appropriate e.g. broken limb;

A member of staff must be referred to the Occupational Health department immediately if the absence is considered to be work related i.e. stress or that a referral at an earlier stage may be beneficial to the member of staff;
Where a member of staff has been absent for 3 months, the manager should complete an Occupational Health referral.

The line manager must complete the referral form (found in the sickness toolkit available  on the intranet)  and it is important  that  this is  completed  correctly  so specific questions can be answered in relation to the member of staff's role and the reason for the absence. The referral must be brought to the attention of the member of staff and signed by the member of staff.

A risk assessment can identify measures or adjustments to help the member of staff return to and remain in work. Occupational Health and the Employee Relations Team can advise the manager on what adjustments could be made to help the member of staff return to work. Examples are:
Allowing a phased return to work– this process may vary in working days and working hours i.e. building up from part time to full time hours, or working day shifts instead of night shifts;

Where a phased return is recommended by Occupational Health and/or Employee Relations then the member of staff will suffer no loss of pay. Where a phased return is not recommended or supported by Occupational Heath then the member of staff will be expected to use accrued annual leave to ensure no loss of pay;
A phased return will usually last for a 28 calendar day period, however in exceptional circumstances this may be extended on advice from
Occupational Health.
Staff should be referred for an Occupational Health assessment in the following situations:
Long term or continuing absence;
Persistent and/or short term absence;
Where any further concerns are identified;
If an illness is identified as work related;
If a member of staff requires additional support and/or adjustments in order to maintain their attendance at work.

Staff must be aware that it may be necessary to discuss relevant health related reports with the appropriate managers and the Employee Relations Team. Occupational Health will explain this further during their appointment and obtain their written consent for this information to be shared.
Returning to Work

It is expected that members of staff provide as much notice as possible of an intended date of return to work to their line manager (nominated deputy). When a member of staff returns to work the line manager will conduct a return to work interview to;
Welcome the member of staff back to the workplace;
Ensure the member of staff is fit to return to work;
The reason for and cause of absence;
If the member of staff requires any further support;
If there are any concerns about levels of attendance.
The return to work form (found in the sickness toolkit available on the intranet) should be completed and signed by the employee.
Sickness and Annual Leave

If a member of staff is sick during planned annual leave and wishes to retain their pre-booked annual leave then they must notify the line manager (nominated deputy) on the first day of their sickness absence. The sickness absence must be recorded. The member of staff must submit a Statement of Fitness for work. On receipt of the document the annual leave will be refunded to the member of staff

Staff will continue to accrue annual leave whilst absent. If staff have been on long term sickness absence and are unable to take their annual leave by the end of the annual leave year they will be able to carry over the remainder of the entitlement based on a calculation of the statutory amount of 28 days or pro rata for part time staff members.

It is recognised that taking annual leave whilst on sickness absence may assist with a staff member's recovery. If a member of staff wishes to pursue this, the line manager (nominated deputy) needs to ensure this is recorded appropriately. Therefore, members of staff may request annual leave to go on holiday whilst on sickness absence from work and the appropriate payment will be made. Members of staff must inform their line manager (nominated deputy) of their intentions and seek agreement as soon as possible. Not doing so may result in annual leave not being authorised. This may also benefit staff members who have exhausted full sickness pay. Annual leave can be taken to top up a staff members pay to full pay.
Working additional hours

For staff who also work additional hours, the line manager of their substantive role will determine if it is appropriate to work additional hours. If there appears to be an excessive or unacceptable pattern of sickness absence, the member of staff may have restrictions to work additional hours imposed. This decision will be undertaken in consultation with Occupational Health and the staff member.
Sick Pay Entitlement

If staff have followed the procedure correctly they will be entitled to occupational sick pay in accordance with the provisions of Section 14 of Agenda for Change NHS Terms and Conditions of Service Handbook as follows:-

data.text: If staff intend to be away from home as part of their convalescence whilst on sick leave, they must discuss this with their manager in advance, both to avoid this being seen as an inappropriate activity during sick leave and to ensure that contact is maintained. In these circumstances it may be appropriate for management to do a referral to Occupational Health for some further advice on this.

Entitlement  to  sick  pay  is  calculated  each  time  an  individual  is  absent  due  to sickness,  but  takes  account  of  the  amount  of  paid  sick leave  taken  during  the previous 12 months. The 12 month period is calculated by working backwards from the date upon which the current sickness absence started.
Absence Triggers

Monitoring attendance is intended to make sure that all members of staff are treated fairly and consistently. Trigger levels are a tool to assist managers in keeping track of the frequency of a member of staff's absences and to highlight at the earliest stage, when management intervention is needed. If the line manager is concerned about the level of a member of staff's attendance or they have reached one of the trigger points outlined below the matter will be raised as follows.
The line manager will hold a meeting with the member of staff if their attendance record falls into one of the following triggers:-
3 periods of sickness absence within a rolling 6 month period or 4 periods of sickness absence over a rolling  month period or
14 calendar days over a rolling 12 month period or
28 consecutive calendar days of sickness absence or
A pattern of sickness absence(s) which cause concern such as days linked to weekends/bank holidays/annual leave, e.g. immediately preceding or recurrent absence on a certain day of the week.
A pattern which occurs after completion of a formal stage monitoring
period, may result in a trigger to the next relevant stage.

Consideration of non escalation will be given to staff with a Disability as detailed in the disability provision of the Equality Act 2010 at any stage of the informal or formal procedure. This may also incorporate a request for reasonable adjustments and these will be considered in line with the Reasonable adjustments Policy.
Monitoring Short Term Absence
There are five key stages to managing sickness absence that the line manager is responsible for:
Completion of the return to work interview.
Informal review meeting.
Stage 1 formal attendance review meeting.
Stage 2 formal attendance review meeting.
Stage 3 formal attendance review hearing.

Effective records to support the management of sickness absence must be kept on each personal file as this information will be audited. Templates of the documentation to be used at all stages are accessible via staff net.

The return to work interview should be completed as soon as possible and preferably on the first day back at work but no later than after 48 hours of the member of staff returning to work. A return to work form should be completed in full and kept on the member of staff's personal file for audit and recording purposes.

If the absence is pregnancy related, the absence should be monitored, support / reasonable adjustments put in place and a risk assessment must be in place and regularly reviewed. Pregnancy related absences will not count towards the triggers.
Informal Review Meeting

Where a member of staff reaches the trigger(s) for an informal review it is important that this is detailed on the return to work form. At this meeting there is no right to be accompanied at this stage. The member of staff is advised of the triggers within the attendance policy and how they have reached this stage.
The purpose of this meeting is for the manager and the member of staff to:
Go through and confirm the recorded absences;
Identify any underlying reasons for the absences;
To agree any support that may be needed / required. This may include a referral to Occupational Health;
To agree an action plan to support improved attendance.

The line manager will write to the member of staff within 7 calendar days and confirm what has been discussed. The member of staff will be given a clear action plan in order to support improved attendance. Staff must be advised that if they have a further absence their absence levels will be reviewed and if the appropriate target is breached the manager will consider invoking the next stage of the attendance management policy.
All of the above must be detailed within the outcome letter. A copy of the letter should be placed on the member of staff's personal file and provided to the member of staff.

The member of staff may progress to stage 1 if there are 3 further occasions of absence or 14 calendar days in 6 months, following the informal meeting. In the case of members of staff with a disability, they may progress to stage 1 if the level of absence agreed at informal stage is not adhered to.
Stage 1 Formal Review Meeting

Where a member of staff reaches stage 1 of the attendance management policy a formal attendance review meeting is required. The purpose of this meeting includes ascertaining what support and/ or reasonable adjustments the member of staff may need to meet acceptable levels of attendance.

The line manager must inform the member of staff in writing of the date and time of the meeting. It is important that the member of staff is given at least 7 calendar days' notice. This meeting will follow the same format as the informal attendance review meeting. Where appropriate and dependant on the facts of the case the discussion will include consideration of what / if any reasonable adjustments can be made to sustain attendance. Staff may be asked to attend a medical assessment with Occupational Health.

A standard invite letter must be sent and should contain the details of the member of staff's absences since the informal meeting. In attendance at this meeting will be the line manager and the member of staff.

A formal attendance review proforma must be used as this will detail the format of the meeting and capture both relevant information and any agreed actions. This proforma (found in the sickness toolkit available on the intranet) must be signed by both the member of staff and the line manager at the meeting and a copy of the proforma is to be retained on the personal file upon completion of the meeting and a copy given to the staff member.

The member of staff should be given a clear action plan in order to support improved attendance. An outcome letter must be sent within 7 calendar days. This must be completed to reflect the content and outcome of the meeting. A Stage review meeting will be held 3 months from the date of the initial Stage 1 meeting and a further outcome letter sent within 7 calendar days. A copy of all communication will be placed on the member of staff's personal file and issued to the member of staff for their records.

The member of staff may progress to stage 2 if they have any further absence within 6 months, following the stage 1 meeting. In the case of staff with a disability, a reasonable level of absence will be agreed at stage 1. The member of staff may progress to Stage 2 if this level is not adhered to.
If the attendance has remained stable or improved the member of staff reverts to the informal part of the process.
17 Stage 2 Formal Meeting

The Stage 2 Formal Meeting will be held with the line manager and an ER representative. The member of staff will be entitled to be accompanied by a recognised trade union representation or a work colleague not acting in a legal capacity. The stage 2 meeting will follow the same format as a Stage 1 attendance review meeting. Where appropriate and dependant on the facts of the case the discussion will include consideration of what / if any reasonable adjustments / support can be introduced to sustain attendance.

The member of staff may progress to stage 3 if they have any further absence within 6 months following the stage 2 meetings. In the case of staff with a disability, a reasonable level of absence will be agreed at stage  The member of staff may progress to Stage 3 if this level is not adhered to.
If the attendance has remained stable or improved the member of staff reverts to the informal part of the process.

A letter detailing the discussion at the stage 2 formal meeting, confirming the details of the standard required and any requirement for reasonable adjustments/support during the review period will be sent to the member of staff within 7 calendar days.
Stage 3 Formal Attendance Hearing.

Staff will be given 7 calendar days' notice of the hearing in writing. The letter will include the right to be accompanied. The purpose of the hearing will be to consider the member of staff's absence record and whether they are capable of maintaining reasonable attendance in the future.

The hearing manager will be a senior manager at Band 7 or above who has the authority to dismiss and supported by an allocated Employee Relations team member. The hearing manager will consider all the information and facts regarding the absence record, the opinion of Occupational Health and the support the organisation has provided to the member of staff. All the facts of the case and possible outcomes will be fully considered in a fair and unbiased manner. Where appropriate and dependant on the facts of the case the discussion will include consideration of what, if any reasonable adjustments / support can be implemented to sustain attendance.
There are a number of outcomes at this stage and this includes further management and review targets, redeployment, ill health retirement or dismissal.

In the event of a member of staff being dismissed they will be paid in lieu of their contractual notice as well as outstanding annual leave accrued up to the last date of employment. All benefits under the contract will come to an end on the date of termination. The member of staff will be notified of the outcome of the hearing in writing within 7 calendar days.
The manager will write to the member of staff detailing the content and outcome of the meeting and provide details of their right of appeal in accordance with the Appeals procedure.
Monitoring Long Term Absence
If a member of staff has a continued absence which is for more than 28 calendar days it will be considered as a Long Term Absence.
The line manager will arrange a well-being meeting to discuss:
Additional support the Trust may be able to provide;
The possibility of returning to work;
Help and support to facilitate a return to work;
Departmental communications to keep the member of staff included with any updates or changes which may have taken place.
Well Being Meetings will be held on a regular basis for example every month. These meetings will be held with the manager and the member of staff only for the first 12 weeks.

Once a member of staff has been absent for 12 weeks, an Employee Relations representative will be in attendance. However, the Head of Employee Relations may determine at any point that Employee Relations support is required in which case the member of staff will also have the right to be represented by a trade union representative or work place colleague.
It is important that members of staff attend both Well Being Meetings and Occupational Health appointments as failure to do so may result in the withdrawal of Occupational Sick Pay.
If a member of staff remains absent for a prolonged period, managers will consider the advice and support from Occupational Health for the following, individual circumstances will be considered:
The nature of their illness;
The likely prognosis for the recovery and/or re-occurrence;
The member of staff's absence record, including spaces between absences.
Any special circumstances;
Whether additional support or adjustments to the work place and/or role would help facilitate a return to work.

There must be clear identification if the condition affecting the member of staff is either terminal or life limiting and if there are no prospects of the member of staff being able to return to work in any capacity. If after considering all the above the manager feels that redeployment or termination of employment is necessary, the member of staff will be invited to an ill Health Capability Hearing.

A well-being proforma (found in the sickness toolkit available on the intranet) must be completed and placed on the member of staff's personal file. The member of staff must also receive a copy of this proforma.
Phased Return

After a period of long term sick it may be appropriate for a member of staff to come back to work on reduced hours and/or amended duties. If Occupational Health recommends a phased return the member of staff will be paid in full but may work amended hours and/or duties.

The length of the phased return will be advised by Occupational Health and will usually last for up to a 28 calendar day period, however in exceptional circumstances this may be extended on advice from Occupational Health.
If Occupational Health do not recommend a phased return, the member of staff and their line manager may agree to support the return to work by using annual leave so that pay is not impacted.
Formal Long Term ill health Capability Hearing

Staff will be given 7 calendar days' notice of the hearing in writing. The purpose of the hearing will be to consider the member of staff's absence record and whether they are capable of maintaining reasonable attendance in the future.

The hearing manager will consider all the information and facts regarding the absence, the opinion of Occupational Health and the support the Trust have provided to the member of staff. All the facts of the case and possible outcomes will be fully considered in a fair and unbiased manner. Where appropriate and dependant on the facts of the case the discussion will include consideration of what / if any reasonable adjustments can be made to facilitate a return to work and to maintain attendance.
It is possible that a member of staff may be dismissed at this stage of the process on the grounds that they are not capable of performing their role on the grounds of ill- health.

In cases where the member of staff has applied for Ill Health retirement and/or if they agree that termination of employment is appropriate, they, or their representative, can submit their request in writing for consideration of termination of employment on the grounds of ill health without their attendance at an ill health capability hearing. In the case of ill health retirement an employee will not be dismissed until all the appropriate paperwork has been completed by the Trust and sent to the NHS pension panel.

Where the member of staff is suffering from a terminal illness there are a variety of options open to the line manager and/or member of staff. The manager would aim, as far as possible, to give the member of staff's interest immediate attention and would try to provide the most financial beneficial result for the member of staff and/or their relatives

Special pension arrangements are available to NHS Pension members who are terminally ill. Line managers should liaise with Employee Relations or the Payroll Department  for  guidance in individual  cases.  An  Ill-Health  retirement  application should be made immediately if terminal illness is confirmed.

In the event of a member of staff being dismissed they will be paid in lieu of their contractual notice as well as outstanding annual leave accrued up to the last date of employment. All benefits under the contract will come to an end on the date of termination. The member of staff will be notified of the outcome of the hearing in writing within  calendar days. This written notification will include details of the reason for termination and provide details of their right of appeal.

Where no return to work date can be identified, a formal ill health Capability hearing is required. The line manager must contact the Employee Relations Advisor in order to ensure that the appropriate Employee Relations representation is available for the hearing.

The member of staff must be informed of the date and time of the hearing and is given at least 7 calendar days' notice. The invite letter is available on the ER page on the hospital intranet and must be issued to the member of staff as part of the management statement of case. The management statement of case template is available on ER page on the hospital intranet and will include all of the relevant information relating to the member of staff's sickness absence history. The member of staff must be advised that an outcome of the hearing could be up to and including dismissal. The staff member is entitled to be accompanied by trade union representative or workplace colleague at a hearing.

The hearing should be heard by a manager with the authority to dismiss and an allocated member of the Employee Relations team. Where appropriate and dependant on the facts of the case the discussion will include consideration of what/if any reasonable adjustments can be made to sustain the member of staff's attendance. Up to date medical advice must be available at the hearing before a decision can be made to terminate employment.

Different procedure arrangements may apply in the case those applying for ill-health retirement or suffering from terminal illness or life limiting conditions. Line Managers should refer to the policy and seek Employee Relations advice

An outcome letter must be completed to reflect the content and outcome of the meeting and also provide details of the member of staff's right to appeal in accordance with the Appeals procedure. A copy is to be placed on the member of staff's personal file and issued to the member of staff for their records.
Unauthorised Absence:
Unauthorised absence applies to all staff if:
They fail to comply with the attendance management reporting procedure;
Absent from work without notification;
Absent from work for any other reason without authorisation.

If a member of staff is absent from work without good cause and/or fails to notify the Trust of their absence, this may be dealt with formally and may result in disciplinary action under the relevant policy.
Action on first day of unauthorised absence

23.1 On the first day of the member of staff's unauthorised absence, the line manager will attempt to contact them, making a note of the means used (telephone or email) and keeping a record of the time. If the member of staff does not answer the telephone, the manager will attempt to leave a voicemail message asking them to return the call. If the manager is unable to contact the member of staff, they may attempt to contact the member of staff's next of kin or listed emergency contact.
Action on second day of unauthorised absence

24.1 On the second day of the member of staff's unauthorised absence, if the manager has again been unable to contact the member of staff and or the member of staff's next of kin or emergency contact, the manager will write to the member of staff detailing their absence and the attempts that have been made to contact them. The letter will say that no satisfactory explanation for the absence has been received, their pay has been withheld and it is required that the member of staff make contact with the manager as soon as possible, but no later than 7 calendar days after the date of the letter. The letter will advise the member of staff that, if they fail to make contact by the given deadline, the Trust will invoke the disciplinary procedure. The line manager must then inform the Payroll Department on day 6 that pay is to be withheld until further notice.
Further action after the deadline

25.1 If, following the deadline, the member of staff has still not contacted the manager, the manager will send the member of staff a letter inviting them to attend a disciplinary hearing to explain their unauthorised absence. The letter should advise the member of staff that the lack of an adequate explanation may result in formal action under the Trusts Disciplinary Policy.
Disciplinary action as a result of unauthorised absence

If the manager makes contact with the member of staff and/or the member of staff returns to work, the manager should conduct an immediate investigation into the reasons for their absence and their lack of contact with the Trust
Pay will be reinstated from the member of staff's return to work date.

If the manager is satisfied with the explanation for the member of staffs absence and lack of contact with the Trust the manager can conduct a return to work interview and document the conversation as a recorded conversation.

If  the  member  of  staff  is  unable  to  provide  a  satisfactory  explanation  for  their unauthorised absence and lack of contact with the Trust the manager may invoke the Trusts Disciplinary Policy.
Countering Fraudulent Activity

The Trust has a zero tolerance to allegations of fraudulent activity.  Any  suspicions of fraudulent activity will be referred to the Trust Counter Fraud Specialist for detailed information  gathering.  Should  such  an  investigation  find  reasonable  grounds  to suspect an offence has been committed, further action will be taken, in accordance with the Trust's counter fraud and corruption policy.
Further advice can be obtained from the Trusts Counter Fraud Specialist.
Training Requirements
28.1 This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.
Monitoring and Audit

All management of sickness absence and outcomes of all cases handled under this policy will be monitored by the Employee Relations team in partnership with the relevant Staff Side Representatives. The aim will be to ensure that any sickness absence cases are managed appropriately as per this policy
